p: Windstorms represent one of the major factors influencing European temperate forests ( Fischer et al., 2013), and their intensity has been increasing during the last few decades ( Gregow et al., 2017). Depending on wind severity, the influence of windstorms may extend from single trees to large areas of forests. Large windstorms, causing forest breakdown, affect the forest ecosystem in a complex way. Changes in forest structure lead to overall changes in microhabitat conditions, such as increased solar radiation connected to increased temperatures and changes in water availability ( Gömöryová et al., 2008), nutrient cycling ( Don et al., 2012), and vegetation cover ( Dietz et al., 2020). Because European temperate forests mainly consist of trees living in symbiosis with ectomycorrhizal (ECM) fungi ( Martin et al., 2016), these fungal symbionts also face these changes.
